History of the RSS Fork

215 words written on Sun, Jun 15 2003

History of the RSS fork. Grr.

This probably doesn‚Äôt interest 90% of my readers, but in the context of this, is quite interesting. {Also, some of my language in that post is more interesting, ‚Äúthe only really adopted use of RDF was rapidly and forcefully dropped on the scene‚Äù was meant to be complimentary, but from Dave W‚Äôs mouth would be a flame, I assume.}

I have been struggling for some time with SWIM‚Äôs data architecture. I am 95% ready to settle on RSS 1.0 as an initial data structure, because it will both serve most of my potential initial users‚Äô needs and it complies with the most widely accepted format for the Semantic Web. And because of it‚Äôs complex namespace-based design, I can extend it (internally) in the future while still complying with the original spec. I just didn‚Äôt know I was choosing sides on such a vicious fight. It had never occurred to me what a big deal the different RSS specs were. One group/org spec‚Äôd RSS 9.x, another RSS 1.0. The acro RSS itself can mean diff things. I publish RSS 9.1. I‚Äôm building the next gen of that content system on RSS 1.0. Big f‚Äôn deal.
